questions.Question: The worship of images (of Buddha) in India began during the period
questions.solution: Solution:		The Kushan Empire was a syncretic empire, formed by the Yuezhi, in the Bactrian territories in the early 1st century. It spread to encompass much of Afghanistan, and then the northern parts of the Indian subcontinent at least as far as Saketa and Sarnath near Varanasi (Benares), where inscriptions have been found dating to the era of the Kushan Emperor Kanishka the Great. Emperor Kanishka was a great patron of Buddhism. He played an important role in the establishment of Buddhism in the Indian subcontinent and its spread to Central Asia and China.

questions.Question: After the Kalinga War, Ashoka decided never to wage any war because?
questions.optionA: After the conquest of Kalinga the political unity of Mauryan India had been achieved
questions.optionB: Ashoka felt apologetic about the destruction of men and material on both sides in the war
questions.optionC: He was moved by the violence, slaughter and sufferings to the combatants and noncombatants in the war
questions.optionD: Shortly after the war he adopted Buddhism which was opposed to violence
questions.solution: Solution:		Ashoka was an Indian Emperor of the Maurya Dynasty , who ruled almost all of the Indian subcontinent from 268 to 232 BCE.The Kalinga war, the sight of such a carnage and massacre of human lives, and the sufferings of the wounde made a deep impression on Ashoka's mind. The unhappiness of the women and children made him very sad and unhappy .He vowed never to make a war again in his life. He decided to devote the rest of his life to the spread of Dharma. Thus the Kalinga war became a turning point of his life.

questions.Question: Ashoka has been particularly influenced by the Buddhist monk
questions.solution: Solution:		Upagupta (c. 3rd Century BC) was a Buddhist monk. According to some stories in the Sanskrit text Ashokavadana, he was the spiritual teacher of the Mauryan emperor Ashoka. Upagupta's teacher was Sanavasi who was a disciple of Ananda, the Buddha's attendant. Due to the absence of his name in Theravada literature, it is assumed that Upagupta was a Sarvastivadin monk.

questions.Question: Which one of the following is not a sect of Buddhism?
questions.solution: Solution:		Digambara ("sky-clad") is one of the two major schools of Jainism, the other being Svetambara (white-clad). questions.solution: Solution:		First Buddhist Council: 400 BC. questions.Question: Who was the patron of the 3rd Buddhist council?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Third Buddhist council was convened in about 250 BCE at Asokarama in Pataliputra, supposedly under the patronage of Emperor Ashoka. The council recommended the ruler Ashoka to expel sixty thousand brahmanic spies as well as reevaluate the Pāli Canon.

questions.solution: Solution:		Buddha has been described as 'an ocean of wisdom and compassion' in Amarakosa. The fifth and sixth verses give various names of Gautama Buddha.

questions.Question: According to Jain Shastra, Manno Sahssisso Bhimo, __________
questions.solution: Solution:		According to Jainas, the world is composed of two different kinds of substances, the Jiva (conscious) and the ajiva (unconscious). These are the uncreated existing constituents of the Universe which impart the necessary dynamics to the Universe by interacting with each other. These constituents behave according to the natural laws and their nature without interference from external entities. Dharma or true religion according to Jainism is Vatthu sahavo dhammo translated as "the intrinsic nature of a substance is its true dharma."

questions.Question: Which among the following is the sacred book of the Buddhists?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Tripitaka (Pali Canon), Mahayana Sutras and the Tibetan Book of the Dead are three major noncanonical Buddhist texts. The Pali Canon, which means "the word of Buddha," includes some of the Buddha's discourse, but it also incorporates the teachings of his pupils.

questions.Question: Which of the following was the cause of the decline of Buddhism?
questions.optionA: Buddhism was founded by a prince
questions.solution: Solution:		The important cause of the decline and fall of Buddhism was the decline of Buddhist Sanghas. The Sanghas became centres of corruption. The discipline of vinay pitaka was violated. The viharas were dominated by ease-loving people. The monks and nuns began to lead lives of pleasure and ease. The Mahayanist and Hinayanist quarreled with each other. Internal conflict proved to be the ruin of Buddhism.

questions.Question: During whose reign did Buddhism become the state religion?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ashoka's personal religion became Buddhism, if not before, then certainly after the Kalinga war. Nevertheless, his patronage led to the expansion of Buddhism in the Mauryan empire and other kingdoms during his rule, and worldwide from about 250 BCE.

questions.Question: In which descent Abhinandannath Tirthankar was born?
questions.solution: Solution:		Abhinandannatha or Abhinandan Swami was the fourth Tirthankara of the present age (Avasarpini). Abhinandananātha is said to have lived for 50 lakh purva. questions.Question: Which of the following place, Buddha was never depicted in a human form but was represented only as a symbol of either two footprints or wheel?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sanchi Stupa, also written Sanci, is a Buddhist complex, famous for its Great Stupa, on a hilltop at Sanchi Town in Raisen District of the State of Madhya Pradesh, India. It is located in 46 kilometres (29 mi) north-east of Bhopal, capital of Madhya Pradesh. The Great Stupa at Sanchi is one of the oldest stone structures in India, and an important monument of Indian Architecture. It was originally commissioned by the emperor Ashoka in the 2nd century BCE. Its nucleus was a simple hemispherical brick structure built over the relics of the Buddha. It was crowned by the chhatri, a parasol-like structure symbolising high rank, which was intended to honour and shelter the relics.

questions.solution: Solution:		Nalanda was a Mahavihara, a large Buddhist monastery, in the ancient kingdom of Magadha (modern-day Bihar) in India. The site is located about 95 kilometres (59 mi) southeast of Patna near the city of Bihar Sharif, and was a centre of learning from the fifth century CE to c. 1200 CE. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.Nalanda flourished under the patronage of the Gupta Empire in the 5th and 6th centuries and later under Harsha, the emperor of Kannauj. The liberal cultural traditions inherited from the Gupta age resulted in a period of growth and prosperity until the ninth century. The subsequent centuries were a time of gradual decline, a period during which the tantric developments of Buddhism became most pronounced in eastern India under the Pala Empire.

questions.solution: Solution:		The capital is carved out of a single block of polished sandstone, and was always a separate piece from the column itself.

questions.Question: Gautama Buddha was born at
questions.solution: Solution:		 According to the Buddhist tradition, Gautama was born in Lumbini, now in modern-day Nepal, and raised in the Shakya capital of Kapilvastu, which may have been either in what is present day Tilaurakot, Nepal or Piprahwa, India.

questions.Question: Name the ruler whose patronage had been enjoyed by Jainism
questions.solution: Solution:		Kharavela was a king of Kalinga in present-day Odisha, India. He ruled somewhere around first or second century BCE. His name is also transliterated as Kharabeḷa. He is the best known king of the Mahameghavahana dynasty.

questions.Question: The Buddha's Eight Fold Path did not include
questions.solution: Solution:		The Eightfold Path consists of eight practices: right view, right resolve, right speech, right conduct, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right samadhi ('meditative absorption or union'). The Noble Eightfold Path is one of the principal teachings of Theravada Buddhism, taught to lead to Arhatship.

questions.Question: Which of the following School of art noted for its vitality and assimilative character just because of Brahmanism, Jainism and Buddhism?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mathura School of art noted for its vitality and assimilative character just because of Brahmanism, Jainism and Buddhism. Mathura art refers to a particular school of Buddhist art, which centered on the city of Mathura, in central northern India, during the period in which Buddhism flourished in India. The art of Mathura is usually contrasted with the Greco-Buddhist art of Gandhara.

questions.Question: During the reign of Kanishka, Buddhism for the first time went to China and from China it went to
questions.solution: Solution:		 Kanishka conquests and patronage of Buddhism played an important role in the development of the Silk Road, and in the transmission of Mahayana Buddhism from Gandhara across the Karakoram range to China and than to Korea and Japan.

questions.Question: According to Jainis, at which place Abhinandannath attained Nirvana?
questions.solution: Solution:		According to Jainis, at Sammed Shikhar Abhinandannath attained Nirvana. Shikharji (Sikharji), Giridih district, Jharkhand, India, is located on Parasnath hill, the highest mountain in the state of Jharkhand. It is the most important Jain Tirtha (pilgrimage site) for the Jains, believed to be the place where twenty of the twenty-four Jain tirthankaras along with many other monks attained Moksha, according to Nirvana Kanda and other texts.

questions.Question: To whom is the introduction of Buddhism into China traditionally attributed?
questions.solution: Solution:		Kasyapa Matanga or Jia Yemoteng was an Indian Buddhist monk who is traditionally believed to have first introduced Buddhism to China in the 1st century CE. According to popular accounts of Chinese Buddhism, Emperor Ming of Han dreamt of a golden deity interpreted as the Buddha and sent a delegation to India.

questions.Question: Ashoka expresses his faith in the Buddhist creed in the
questions.solution: Solution:		Ashoka expresses his faith in the Buddhist creed in the Bhabru edict.

questions.Question: According to Jains, what was the number of Gandhars of Sumtinath Tirthankar?
questions.solution: Solution:		According to Jains, there was 100 number of Gandhars of Sumtinath Tirthankar.

questions.Question: Buddhism was divided into Mahayana and Hinayana during the reign of
questions.solution: Solution:		After the death of Buddha, Buddhism was divided into two sects namely Mahayana and Hinayana. The terms Hinayana (Lesser Vehicle or Modest Vehicle) and Mahayana (Greater Vehicle or Vast Vehicle) originated in The Prajnaparamita Sutras (The Sutras on Far-Reaching Discriminating Awareness, The Perfection of Wisdom Sutras). It was divided during the reign of Kanishka.

questions.Question: Select the correct language in which Jain and Buddhist literature were written?
questions.solution: Solution:		Pali and Prakrit rose to prominence when these were adopted by Buddhist and Jain Sect in ancient India as their sacred language.

questions.Question: Which of the following rulers did not enter the Buddhist Cold?
questions.solution: Solution:		Samudragupta did not enter the Buddhist Cold.

questions.Question: Buddha, Dhamma and Sangha together are known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Triratna, (Sanskrit: "Three Jewels") Pali Ti-ratana, also called Threefold Refuge, in Buddhism the Triratna comprises the Buddha, the dharma (doctrine, or teaching), and the sangha (the monastic order, or community).

questions.Question: Which is the ultimate goal of education in Jainism?
questions.solution: Solution:		In Jainism, moksha is the highest and the noblest objective that a soul should strive to achieve. In fact, it is the only objective that a person should have; other objectives are contrary to the true nature of soul. With the right view, knowledge and efforts all souls can attain this state. That is why Jainism is also known as mokṣamārga or the "path to liberation".

questions.Question: The monolithic image of Jain Saint 'Gomatiswara' is at __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Gommateshwara Statue is a 57-foot (17 m) high monolithic statue located on Vindyagiri at Shravanbelagola in the Indian state of Karnataka. Vindyagiri Hill is one of the two hills in Shravanabelagola; the other is Chandragiri, which is also a seat of several ancient Jain centers, much older than Gommateshwara statue.

questions.Question: Who among the following rulers had embraced Jainism?
questions.solution: Solution:		Chandragupta Maurya embraced Jainism towards the end of his life and stepped down from the throne in favour of his son Bindusara.

questions.Question: Under which tree Sumtinath Tirthankar received Kaivalya Gyan?
questions.solution: Solution:		Under Priyangu tree Sumtinath Tirthankar received Kaivalya Gyan.

questions.Question: The principles of Ashoka's Dharma (Dhamma) were taken from
questions.optionD: The moral virtues of all Indian religions of that period
questions.solution: Solution:		The principles of Ashoka's Dharma (Dhamma) were taken from the moral virtues of all Indian religions of that period.

questions.Question: Mention the place where Buddha attained enlightenment.
questions.solution: Solution:		Bodh Gaya is a religious site and place of pilgrimage associated with the Mahabodhi Temple Complex in Gaya district in the Indian state of Bihar. It is famous as it is the place where Gautama Buddha is said to have obtained Enlightenment (Pali: bodhi) under what became known as the Bodhi Tree.

questions.Question: Buddha means
questions.solution: Solution:		Buddha literally means enlightened one or a person who attained Boddhi which means wisdom (highest intellectual or virtue). It means a person who attained highest level of life status.

questions.Question: Outside India, Buddhism was first accepted in
questions.solution: Solution:		The first evidence of the religion spreading outside India coincides with Ashoka's rule as he sent emissaries to Sri Lanka and an area called Suvarnabhumi.

questions.Question: Which among the following is the great Buddhist work consisting of dialogues between the Indo-Greek King Menander and the Buddhist philosopher Nagasena?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Milindapanha is one of the great classics of Pali Buddhist literature, a spirited dialogue between the Greek king Milinda and the Buddhist sage Nagasena.

questions.Question: What is the meaning of Kaivalya Gyan (enlightenment) received by Abhinandannath Tirthankar?
questions.solution: Solution:		The meaning of Kaivalya Gyan (enlightenment) received by Abhinandannath Tirthankar was brahma Vidya.

questions.Question: The first Tirthankara of the Jains was
questions.solution: Solution:		The first tirthankara in this present time cycle was Rishabhanatha, who is credited for formulating and organising humans to live in a society harmoniously.

questions.Question: The language in which Buddha preached?
questions.solution: Solution:		According to Pali Canon, Buddha taught in local or folks language. He avoided the scholars' language, i.e. Sanskrit.

questions.Question: Gautam Buddha as a prince was known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The Buddha, or "enlightened one," was born Siddhartha (which means "he who achieves his aim") Gautama to a large clan called the Shakyas in Lumbini, (today, modern Nepal) in the 6th century B.C.

questions.Question: Ashoka was much influenced by Buddhist monk called
questions.solution: Solution:		Upagupta was a Buddhist monk. According to some stories in the Sanskrit text Ashokavadana, he was the spiritual teacher of the Mauryan emperor Ashoka.

questions.Question: Which ruler founded the famous Vikramshila University for the Buddhists?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vikramashila was founded by Pāla king Dharmapala in the late 8th or early 9th century.

questions.Question: Which of the following is/are mantra of Jainism?
questions.optionA: All sinful acts are renounced for life-long
questions.optionB: All philanthropies acts are renounced for life-long
questions.solution: Solution:		All sinful acts are renounced for life-long is mantra of Jainism.

questions.Question: Name the ruler whose reign was a witness to both Vardhaman Mahavira and the Buddha preaching their respective doctrines?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bimbisara reign was a witness to both Vardhaman Mahavir and the Buddha preaching their respective doctrine.

questions.Question: The Jaina saint credited with the spread of Jainism in Karnataka (south India) was
questions.solution: Solution:		 Bhadrabahu was the Jaina saint that credited with the spread of Jainism in Karnataka (south India).

questions.Question: For how many years Ajitnath Tirthankar practise harsh austerity?
questions.solution: Solution:		He led a pious life in spite of the available princely grandeur. At an appropriate time, he became an ascetic under Arindam Suri. Meditating about the omniscient and liberated souls and indulging in harsh penance for 12 years, he purified his soul to a level where he could earn the Tirthankar-nam-and-gotra-karma. Completing his age, he reincarnated as a god in the Viaya- anuttar-dimension. After completing his age in the dimension of gods, he descended into the womb of queen Vijaya Devi, wife of king Jitshaturu of Ayodhya .

questions.Question: Before starting of an Era, what was the last karma given by Rishabhanatha other than agriculture, ink, sword, craft and service?
questions.solution: Solution:		Before starting of an Era, Business was the last karma given by Rishabhanatha other than agriculture, ink, sword, craft and service, he taught agriculture hence, the means of agriculture, business and self-protection.

questions.Question: What is the name of the preaching mudra of gesture, in which the Buddha is depicted delivering his first sermon, In the Gandhara Sculptures?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dharmachakra mudra is one of such interesting and unique hand gestures used in Buddha statues which means the wheel of Dharma in Buddhism. The Dharmachakra mudra is also known as gesture of Teaching of the Wheel of Dharma. This gesture depicts one of the most important moment in Buddha's life as he performed the Dharmachakra mudra in his first sermon in Sarnath after he attained enlightenment.

questions.Question: Gandhara school of art came into existence in
questions.solution: Solution:		The Gandhara school of art came into existence in Mahayana sect. Mahayana sect believes in idols worship of Buddha and Bodhisattvas.

questions.Question: The site of birth (nativity) of Gautam Buddha is marked by
questions.solution: Solution:		Ashoka (r 272-231 BC) was a Mauryan king who converted to Buddhism in the middle of his reign and spent the rest of his life propagating his dharma (law). In order to spread the word of Buddhism he had numerous edicts inscribed on pillars and placed throughout his empire.

questions.Question: What was the name assigned to Rishabhnath Tirthankar because of the mark on his right leg?
questions.solution: Solution:		Rishabh was the name assigned to Rishabhnath Tirthankar because of the mark on his right leg( bull mark and bull literally means Rishabh).

questions.Question: What was the name of the mother of Rishabhnath?
questions.solution: Solution:		According to Jain traditional accounts, he was born to king Nabhi and queen Marudevi in the north Indian city of Ayodhya, also called Vinita. He had two wives, Sunanda and Sumangala. Sumangala is described as the mother of his ninety-nine sons (including Bharata) and one daughter, Brahmi.

questions.Question: The famous Buddhist scholar Ashvaghosha was a contemporary of which one of the following?
questions.solution: Solution:		Kanishka I or Kanishka the Great, an emperor of the Kushan dynasty in the second century (c. 127–150 CE), is famous for his military, political, and spiritual achievements. Asvaghosa or Ashvaghosh was a Buddhist philosopher, dramatist, poet and orator from India. He was born in Saketa in northern India. He is believed to have been the first Sanskrit dramatist.

questions.Question: In Buddhism 'Bull' is related to what incident of Buddha's life?
questions.solution: Solution:		In Buddhism 'Bull' is related to Janma(Birth) incident of Buddha's life Birth.

questions.Question: What is the moral of the horse?
questions.solution: Solution:		All the three moral of the horse i.e, Politeness, Restraint and Knowledge.

questions.Question: The fourth Buddhist Council was held at
questions.solution: Solution:		Fourth Buddhist Council was held in the Sarvastivada tradition, said to have been convened by the Kushan emperor Kanishka, in 78 AD at Kundalban in Kashmir.

questions.Question: What was the name of the father of Rishabhanatha Tirthankar?
questions.solution: Solution:		According to Jain traditional accounts, he was born to king Nabhi and queen Marudevi in the north Indian city of Ayodhya, also called Vinita. He had two wives, Sunanda and Sumangala. Sumangala is described as the mother of his ninety-nine sons (including Bharata) and one daughter, Brahmi.

questions.Question: Vardhamana Mahavira is also known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Vardhamana Mahavira is also known as 'Jina', the one who conquered temptations for sensual pleasures, and hence the name Jainism for the religion he shaped up and propagated from the teachings of his predecessors.

questions.Question: The tutor of Alexander, the Great was
questions.solution: Solution:		During his youth, Alexander was tutored by Aristotle until age 16. After Philip's assassination in 336 BC, he succeeded his father to the throne and inherited a strong kingdom and an experienced army.

questions.Question: The Pitaka that contains pronouncements attributed to the Buddha, laying down numerous rules for the conduct of the order is
questions.solution: Solution:		The Vinaya Pitaka contains pronouncements attributed to Buddha, laying down numerous rules for the conduct of the order.

questions.Question: The Buddhist monk who spread Buddhism in Tibet was
questions.solution: Solution:		Padmasambhava also known as Guru Rimpoche the Indian Buddhist monk spread the Buddhism in Tibet. He even helped in the construction of first Buddhist monastery in Tibet. In Tibetan Buddhism, he is a character of a genre of literature called terma, an emanation of Amitābha that is said to appear to tertöns in visionary encounters and a focus of guru yoga practice, particularly in the Rimé schools.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not the "Tri Ratna" of Jainism?
questions.solution: Solution:		In Jainism the three jewels (also referred to as ratnatraya) are understood as samyagdarshana ("right faith"), samyagjnana ("right knowledge"), and samyakcharitra ("right conduct"). The Triratna is symbolized frequently in art as a trident.

questions.Question: The original Buddhist religious texts had been written in
questions.solution: Solution:		The sacred book of Buddhism is called the Tripitaka (called Tipitaka in Pali). It is also called the Pali Canon, after the language in which it was first written. The ancient Indian language, Pali, is very close to the language that the Buddha himself spoke. Buddhism is based on Buddha's teachings.

questions.Question: Where was the first Buddhist Council held?
questions.solution: Solution:		According to the scriptures of all Buddhist schools, the first Buddhist Council was held soon after the death of the Buddha, dated by the majority of recent scholars around 400 BCE, under the patronage of the king Ajatashatru with the monk Mahakasyapa presiding, at Sattapanni caves Rajgriha (now Rajgir).

questions.Question: Who was the first nun of Gautama Buddha?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mahapajapati Gotami (Pali; Sanskrit Mahaprajapati Gautamī) was the step-mother and maternal aunt (mother's sister) of the Buddha. In Buddhist tradition, she was the first woman to seek ordination for women, which she did from Gautama Buddha directly, and she became the first bhikkhuni (Buddhist nun).

questions.Question: Which one of the following is not included in the 'Eight Fold Path' of Buddhism?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Eightfold Path consists of eight practices: right view, right resolve, right speech, right conduct, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right samadhi ('meditative absorption or union'). The Noble Eightfold Path is one of the principal teachings of Theravada Buddhism, taught to lead to Arhatship.

questions.Question: The Jaina literature is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Jain Literature - Agam literature consists of many texts, which are the sacred books of the Jain religion. They are written in the Ardha-magadhi Prakrit language. Non-agam literature consists of commentary and explanation of Agam literature, and independent works, compiled by ascetics and scholars.

questions.Question: The earlier Buddhist sculptures had shied away from depicting the image of the Buddha, except through such symbols as
questions.solution: Solution:		The footprint, which denotes both his former physical presence on earth and his temporal absence. The bodhi tree, which represents the place of his enlightenment (under the tree) and comes to symbolize the enlightenment experience itself. The stupa, the reliquary in which the Buddha's physical remains are contained a powerful symbol of both his physical death and continued presence in the world.

questions.Question: Who was Ajitnath Tirthankara in his previous life?
questions.solution: Solution:		The soul that became Bhagavan Ajitnath, in its earlier incarnation, was the great king Vimalvahan of Susima city in Mahavideh area. He purified his soul to a level where he could earn the Tirthankar-nam-and-gotra-karma. When king Jitshatru became old and wanted to devote the last part his life to spiritual pursuit.

questions.Question: After receipt of Diksha, with which food Abhinandannath Tirthankar initiated first Parna?
questions.solution: Solution:		After receipt of Diksha,Abhinandannath Tirthankar initiated kheer for first Parna.

questions.Question: The aim of Ashoka's Dhamma was
questions.solution: Solution:		The policy of Dhamma also laid stress on non-violence and peace, which was to be practiced by giving up war and conquests and also as a restraint on the killing of animals. However, Ashoka realized that a certain display of his political might may be necessary to keep the primitive forest-dwelling tribes in check.

questions.Question: The Buddha
questions.optionB: was non-committal on the theory of Karma
questions.optionC: believed in the theory of Karma
questions.optionD: suggested an alternative to the theory of Karma
questions.solution: Solution:		The cycle of rebirth is determined by karma, literally "action". In the Buddhist tradition, karma refers to actions driven by intention (cetanā), a deed done deliberately through body, speech or mind, which leads to future consequences.

questions.Question: Which Buddhist literature consists of dialogues between the Buddha and his followers?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Sutta Pitaka is the second of the three divisions of the Tripitaka or Pali Canon, the Pali collection of Buddhist writings of Theravada Buddhism. The Sutta Pitaka contains more than 10,000 suttas attributed to the Buddha or his close companions.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not a holy book of Jainism?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Sutta Pitaka is the second of the three divisions of the Tripitaka or Pali Canon, the Pali collection of Buddhist writings of Theravada Buddhism.

questions.Question: Which one of the following ruler was not contemporary to 'Buddha'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mahapadma Nanda was the first ruler of Nanda Dynasty. He founded the dynasty in the year 424 BC and ruled for almost 62 years till 362 BC. He was not contemporary to Buddha.

questions.Question: The last in the succession of Jaina Tirthankaras was
questions.solution: Solution:		Mahavira, also known as Vardhamāna, was the last and twenty-fourth tirthankara (ford-maker) who revived Jainism. In the Jain tradition, it is believed that Mahavira was born in the early part of the 6th century BC into a royal kshatriya family in present-day Bihar, India.

questions.Question: For how many years Sumtinath Tirthankar prayed?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sumtinath Tirthankar prayed 20 years.

questions.Question:
I. The Ikshvaku rulers of southern India were antagonistic towards Buddhism.
II. The Pala rulers of eastern India were patrons of Buddhism.
Which of these statement (s) is/are correct?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Pala rulers of eastern India were patrons of Buddhism. Dharmapala (ruled 8th century) was the second ruler of the Pala Empire of Bengal region in the Indian Subcontinent. He was the son and successor of Gopala, the founder of the Pala Dynasty. He greatly expanded the boundaries of the empire, and made the Palas a dominant power in the northern and eastern India.
